definition:
We call an open set $G \subset {\mathbb{C}}^n$ a [*Reinhardt domain*]{}
if $(z_1,\ldots,z_n) \in G$ implies that
$(e^{i\theta_1}z_1,\ldots,e^{i\theta_n}z_n) \in G$ for all real
$\theta_1,\ldots,\theta_n$.

The reason for studying these kinds of domains is that Reinhardt domain
are the domains of convergence of power series in several complex
variables. Note that in one complex variable, a Reinhardt domain is just
a disc.

Note that the intersection of Reinhardt domains is still a Reinhardt
domain, so for every Reinhardt domain, there is a smallest Reinhardt
domain which contains it.

Suppose that $G$ is a Reinhardt domain which contains 0 and that
$\tilde{G}$ is the smallest Reinhardt domain such that
$G \subset \tilde{G}$. Then any function holomorphic on $G$ has a
holomorphic to $\tilde{G}$.

It actually turns out that a Reinhardt domain is a domain of
convergence.

examples of Reinhardt domains in ${\mathbb{C}}^n$ are polydiscs such as
$\underbrace{{\mathbb{D}} \times \cdots \times {\mathbb{D}}}_n$ where
${\mathbb{D}} \subset {\mathbb{C}}$ is the unit disc.
